questions.stem: The following family health unit provides all of the following services except:
options: Treatment of upper respiratory tract infection.

questions.stem: You are reading an article about the common presentations at the family medicine outpatient clinic and found that one of the commonest presentation is:
When you discuss with this patient weight management you are fulfilling which of the following family physician core competency?
Why are you going to refer him for tertiary care?
options: To Endocrinologist to manage his high blood sugar.
To Internist for follow up of his condition.
To ophthalmologist to screen for retinal changes.
To Emergency to manage diabetic coma.

questions.stem: Referring this patient to an ophthalmologist for screening for diabetic retinopathy is considered what type of referral?

You are working in a family medicine clinic and found that one of your colleagues refer all diabetic patients to endocrinologist with unjustified referral for transferring patient’s responsibility. You will tell him:
options: Keep doing this for the sake of the patient.
Referral is sharing and not transferring responsibility.
Referral is ok so long you didn’t exceed 30% of your patients.

questions.stem: You are assessing the physical growth of a 2-months-old boy. The main parameter of assessment is:

A 6-month-old girl is brought to the family medicine clinic by her mother for common cold. The mother is asking you about the developmental milestones that should be attained by the child at this age. You told her that she can

A mother of a 12-month-old boy is asking you about the ideal weight for her child. His birthweight was 3 kg and he looks thinner than boys of his age at the nursery. Examination is within normal, his growth chart as seen in the figure above. What are you going to tell her?
options: His weight is within normal no need to worry.
He is now below the expected and need further assessment.
He needs immediate referral to pediatrician.
He needs immediate abdominal US and CT scan.

questions.stem: A mother brings her 3 years old daughter for regular check up. Her weight is 21 kgs above the 97th percentile. Her height and head circumference are at 50th percentiles. The mother is concerned as more than 1 family member is obese and she is worried about her child’s future risk. How are you going to confirm her condition?
options: She is obese based on the weight growth charts.
Calculate her BMI and if > 30, she is obese.
Calculate her BMI and plot it on appropriate curves.

questions.stem: This is the height growth chart of a 16-year-old boy. What is the most common cause of this condition?
options: c. Chromosomal abnormality e.g., down & turner syndrome

questions.stem: A-boy is brought to family medicine clinic by his mother for hearing assessment before taking his scheduled set of immunization. When should screening for hearing problems start at PHC?

The mother of a 1-month-old girl is presenting to you concerned that her daughter has this lesion. She says that she doesn’t notice everyday but most of the days her eyes are abnormal. Examination revealed the following photo. Which of the following test will you use?
A 6-month-old boy is presenting with his mother for immunization. His history is free. According to AAP he should be screened for anemia at the age of:
The mother of a 2-month-old baby ask you about vitamins. She is breastfeeding her baby and wants iron as her sister’s baby, who was given iron supplementation. What will be your answer ?
options: vitamin D supplementation of 400 IU daily is recommended for infants who are breast fed
iron supplementation is recommended because breast milk has less iron than formula
no supplementation of any sort is needed for breastfed infants until 1 year of age

questions.stem: The mother of a 7-year-old boy is presenting to you asking about the recommended physical activity for her child. You told her that moderate intensity is recommended daily for:
While taking history from a 14-year-old adolescent presenting to you for health maintenance, you started taking psychosocial history by asking about HEADSSS. D represents which of the following?
You are screening an adolescent for pre-sports participation. He should be screened for all of the following Except:
A 13-year-old adolescent is presenting to you for nutritional advice to prevent obesity. You told him that regarding the food guide pyramid, he should receive daily 6 servings of:
options: Dairy products as milk and yogurt.

questions.stem: The mother of an 11-year-old girl who has completed all her childhood vaccines is asking you about her due vaccine for this age group. You will recommend for her:

A 24-year-old woman and her 26-year-old fiancé come for premarital counselling. They are first cousins. Neither has any current health issues, but they express concern about passing genetic conditions to their future children. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this couple?
options: No further action is needed since they are asymptomatic
Advise them to cancel this marriage
Refer them for genetic counselling and carrier screening
Recommend routine premarital blood tests only

questions.stem: A 27-year-old pregnant female is presenting to you for ANC. This is her second pregnancy. Her first child suffered from the following lesion. What is the dose of folic acid that is recommended for her in this pregnancy to prevent recurrence of this condition?

A 29-year-old primigravida is presenting to you for ANC. Her medical and family history is free except that her sister has a baby with the following condition. What is the screening test she should do in her first trimester?

A 28-year-old woman in her 27th week of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She doesn’t have any complaints. Examination is normal. The patient is asked to ingest 50 mg of glucose and have her blood glucose checked in one hour; it returns as 145 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
options: Do a fasting blood glucose level.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old female is presenting to you for postnatal assessment. Her pregnancy was free except for pregnancy induced hypertension that was controlled. When should she have her blood pressure measured?

A 22-year-old, 2 weeks postnatal female reported passage of drops of urine while coughing or sneezing otherwise, she doesn’t complain of urine leakage. Her examination is free. What will you ask her to do?
A 3-days-old boy is presenting to you with his mother with the following lesion. What is your management?
options: Squeeze the nipple to release any milk
Patch the nipple to prevent milk secretion
Reassurance the condition is self limited

questions.stem: A 5-year-old girl is brought in for bedwetting. She is otherwise healthy and has no daytime symptoms. Her parents are concerned but not distressed. They have not yet tried any interventions. What is the most appropriate first-line management?

An 18-year-old female college student comes with her mother to see you in the office. She started having mild acne 4 months ago. She has been using OTC topical creams. She mentions that it worked initially but not anymore. Her mother is concerned because the patient is embarrassed to go to college because of the acne getting worse. Examination as seen. What would you prescribe for her?
options: Doxycycline 100 mg daily with benzoyl peroxide cream
Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid 625 mg twice per day

questions.stem: A 14-year-old girl comes to your office with a 6-month history of lower midabdominal pain. The pain is colicky in nature, radiates to the back and upper thighs, begins with onset of menses, and lasts for 2 to 4 days. She has missed several days of school during the past 2 months because the pain was so severe. Menarche began 18 months ago, and her menses became regular 6 months ago. Physical examination, including abdomen, is normal. The patient has normal growth and development including secondary sexual development. How are you going to treat this patient?
options: Reassurance and explanation that this is normal

questions.stem: Mrs. Magda 38 years old, has a family history of cancer breast. Based on that history, you decide to refer her to breast mammography. Regardless of her family history, when should Mrs. Magda starts her screening for cancer breast:
What other screening strategies are used for colorectal cancer other than fecal occult blood?
A 21 years old male is concerned about colorectal cancer and wishes to screen for it. He has no risk factor for colorectal cancer, what would you tell him?
options: a) You can start screening at 50 years.
b) You can start screening at 55 years.
c) You can start screening at 60 years.
d) You can start screening at 45 years.

questions.stem: Mr. Ali is concerned about his father's health. He asks about when he should give his father the pneumococcal vaccine?
You asked Mr. Salah to do the clock-drawing test. His result as shown in the picture refers to abnormality in his?

A 68-year-old white woman presents complaining of low back pain for exactly 2weeks after a minimal fall. She has no history of fever, unexplained weight loss, diabetes, or cancer, her physical examination revealed vertebral tenderness, the rest of examination is free. which of the following may be the cause of this back pain?
A 45-year-old patient presents with new onset back pain along with saddle anaesthesia and recent onset of urinary retention. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the name of this test:

A 42 years old male, presents with a 6-week history of persistent sadness, loss of interest in work, poor sleep, and decreased appetite. He has lost 4 kg unintentionally. He denies hallucinations or mania. On examination, he appears withdrawn and tearful. Which of the following best confirms the diagnosis of major depressive disorder?
options: a) Presence of low mood and anhedonia for at least 1 week.
b) Presence of low mood and anhedonia for at least 2 weeks, with functional impairment.
c) Presence of fatigue and poor concentration for at least 4 weeks.
d) Presence of low mood, anhedonia, and hallucinations for 2 days.

questions.stem: Which tool is used to diagnose depression in older adults?
You are giving some advice to a 43-year hypertensive male with a blood pressure 138/88 about his diet. You tell him to add fiber to his diet by eating:
You are giving some advice to a 30-year asthmatic female. So, you tell her that to prevent asthma attacks she should try and do all the following EXCEPT……
options: b) Keep surroundings as free as possible from asthma triggers.
c) Take medications only when he or she feels like it.

questions.stem: What this device is used for?:
options: b) To measure peak inspiratory flow.
d) To diagnose and monitor asthma.

questions.stem: Mr Ibrahim 40-Year-Old banker is newly diagnosed with type 2 DM. After detailed history, examination and investigation, he has low risk for diabetic foot. As his treating physician, you should examine his feet every:
options: d) There Is no need to examine his feet unless a red flag appears.

questions.stem: Mr Ibrahim 40-Year-Old banker is newly diagnosed with type 2 DM. You give him how to care for his feet. Which of the following practices is NOT recommended for preventing diabetic foot complications?
options: a) Inspecting feet daily for cuts, blisters, and sores.
b) Wearing tight-fitting shoes to protect the feet.
c) Keeping feet clean and dry.
d) Moisturizing feet daily, avoiding the areas between the toes.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old female patient is pregnant and wants to quit smoking to ensure a healthy pregnancy. She smokes about 10 cigarettes a day. What is the safest smoking cessation method for her during pregnancy?

A 40-year-old male patient with a history of heart disease. He is concerned about the potential weight gain associated with quitting smoking. Which of the following strategies can help him manage weight gain while quitting smoking?
A 55-year-old male traveler with a history of diabetes and peripheral neuropathy is planning a trip to Southeast Asia. He is concerned about the risk of foot ulcers. What advice would you give him?
options: d) Skip foot hygiene during the trip.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old male traveler plans to travel widely in sub-Saharan Africa in August for 4 weeks, leaving on 12 August. He has had no previous travel vaccines. You see him on 1 August. Which of the following is the most important and appropriate single vaccine you would recommend?

A 35-year-old female traveler is flying from New York to Tokyo. She has no significant medical history, except for taking COCs for 5 years. She is concerned about her risk of VTE during the long flight. What advice would you give her?
options: a) Avoid alcohol during the flight.
c) Take a direct flight without layovers.

questions.stem: An 84-year-old female, Mrs. Nabila, presents to your emergency department (ED) after a collapse at home. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is 6. You decide to take her to CT without intubation, and the scan reveals a massive intracerebral hemorrhage. When breaking this news to Mrs. Nabila, which communication principle is essential?
options: a) Using medical jargon to ensure accuracy.
b) Providing vague information to soften the impact.

questions.stem: You are an oncologist. Mrs. Rasha, a 55-year-old woman, had a breast biopsy a week ago. She comes in with the pathology report which says that she has breast cancer. What is the purpose of using a ‘warning shot’ phrase when delivering bad news?
options: c) To avoid the conversation altogether.
d) To prepare the listener for difficult information.
